entry.title: E-Invoice new features with Release 2511 and 2602 incl. PDF
entry.content:
Since the release 2511 I see a new field in Corporate Accounts under facet Communication >  Collaboration (see screenshot)

The same will be introduced for private accounts with the release 2602.

Why was this introduced, what does it do ?

At first glance, this appears to contradict the concept of an e‚Äëinvoice scenario.

Since we introduced the e‚Äëinvoice functionality, we have received strong customer demand to optionally include the invoice as a PDF in addition to the standard XML-based e‚Äëinvoice. The background is that private individuals can now also request e‚Äëinvoices, and XML/XSLT formats are not user‚Äëfriendly for human readers. Therefore, we agreed to support this option.

The question is: Will this change anything, or is there anything I need to be aware of?

When using the standard e‚Äëinvoice scenario as designed, only the XML file (including its embedded attachments) is sent.

If you enable the option ‚ÄúE‚ÄëInvoice including PDF,‚Äù the email will include the PDF version of the invoice in addition to the XML file. Any attachments will continue to be included as binary content embedded within the XML.

entry.title: Re: Inter-company billing transfer IDOC issue(about enhance)
entry.content:
Standard SAP behavior is when an inter‚Äëcompany billing document is created, an IDoc type like ACC_DOCUMENT INVOIC is generated and forwarded to FI. The account determination (via OBCB, EWLNR key) decides which G/L accounts are hit:

  • EWLNR='*' ‚Üí cost account (e.g., 51110090).
  • EWLNR='99890007' ‚Üí revenue account (e.g., 70100001).

For cost accounts, SAP expects quantity fields (because they are often linked to CO objects). For revenue accounts, the posting schema may not expect quantities, depending on how the account category is configured.

Why the error happens is because, the IDoc segment (e.g., E1EDP01 or ACCIT) carries quantity fields by default. When the line is mapped to a revenue account, the FI posting logic doesn‚Äôt expect a quantity ‚Üí mismatch ‚Üí error. This is aggravated by the fact that screen variant / field status group for revenue accounts suppresses quantity fields.

As already suggested, you can explore EXIT_SAPLIEDI_101 which is a valid and recommended place to implement the clearing of quantity fields for revenue accounts but for information, it is an older enhancement technique (CMOD) and less flexible than BADIs.

Having said that, couple of enhancement options are there where you can manipulate the IDoc before posting

User Exit in IDoc Processing

  • For ACC_DOCUMENT: EXIT_SAPLFACI_001 (function exit for FI IDoc).
  • For INVOIC: EXIT_SAPLVEDF_002 or BADI IDOC_DATA_MAPPER.

You can clear or suppress the quantity field for revenue lines before the IDoc is posted.

BADI / Enhancement

  • BADI_ACC_DOCUMENT ‚Üí allows manipulation of accounting document line items before posting.
  • You can add logic: IF account = revenue account THEN clear quantity fields.

entry.title: Inside the Regulatory Content Service: Everything You Can Access
entry.content:
If you‚Äôve ever wondered why your system doesn‚Äôt show the newest regulatory phrases, lists, or templates right after we announce ‚Äúnew content available,‚Äù you‚Äôre not alone. Those announcements mean new content packages are useable via the Regulatory Content Service‚Äînot that every installed system is automatically updated. To access all the embedded content, you‚Äôll need to be on the latest release of SAP S/4HANA for product compliance. Below, you‚Äôll find a clear mapping of what content is available today and the specific system versions that deliver it, so you can see exactly what you get now‚Äîand what an upgrade unlocks.

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2021 release, the system consumes new and updated regulatory phrases

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2023 release, the system consumes listed substance content

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2023 Feature Pack 3 release, the system consumes new and updated regulatory graphics

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2023 Feature Pack 3 release, the system consumes new and updated dangerous goods regulations

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2025 release, the system consumes new and updated product marketability regulations

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2025 release, the system consumes new and updated safety data sheets regulations

More content is planned to be made accessible in the future. If you have questions, please feel free to leave a comment or message me via LinkedIn.

1Y - INST - A

Waiting for a kind answer

Thanks in advance

entry.title: Re: eInvoicing Direct Debit SEPA Mandate #COE#SW01
entry.content:
Latest reply from SAP: 

We have analyzed your incident. The root cause is that when a Billing Document is created using the Billing Document Request Excel upload, the SEPA Mandate Reference is not populated since the standard Excel upload template does not include a field for SEPA Mandate Reference.

It is a known limitation and unfortunately the desired functionality is not available.

At the moment, the solution for Belgium SEPA Direct Debit scenarios would be to use SD-based billing process to ensure full SEPA and e-invoicing compliance. When billing documents are created via Sales Order -> Billing or Contact-> Billing, the SEPA Mandate Reference is correctly derived and passed through to the Belgium e-invoice.

In case there is wish to request a new functionality or product enhancement, SAP has defined a process and tool called Customer Influence (attached SAP Note 2812948), which allows customers to log improvement request themselves and have the ability to work more directly with our product management.

entry.title: How AI in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 Is Transforming CRM Adoption, Execution, and Business Value
entry.content:
‚è±This article takes about 10 minutes to read

Introduction

Sales and service organizations are operating under unprecedented pressure. Customers expect fast, relevant, and personalized interactions, while internal teams are tasked with managing increased complexity, more data, and multiple channels - often with the same or fewer resources.

SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 represents a fundamental shift in how CRM supports this reality. It is no longer just a system of record, but a system of intelligence, guidance, and automation, powered by SAP Business AI.

Today, SAP delivers 30+ AI capabilities and use cases connected to Sales and Service Cloud V2, spanning Machine Learning, predictive AI, generative productivity, and agentic automation. This article explains what those capabilities are, how they map to real sales and service processes, and how the next evolution - AI Agents - builds on this foundation without hype or overstatement.

That being said, this blog is intended as a practical SAP Sales and Service V2 AI reference asset for consultants, architects, CIOs, IT leaders, and business stakeholders.

Why AI in CRM Is No Longer Optional

Most CRM challenges today are not caused by a lack of functionality. They stem from missing context and excessive manual effort.

Sales and service teams commonly struggle with:

  • Manually searching through emails, documents, complex Excel spreadsheets, and historical cases
  • Repeating administrative documentation instead of engaging customers
  • Interpreting customer intent across fragmented interactions
  • Scaling personalization across regions and languages
  • Knowing which lead, opportunity, or case deserves attention - now!

AI in Sales & Service Cloud V2 directly addresses these challenges inside the flow of work, reducing friction instead of adding new tools.

One Coherent AI Strategy with Complementary Layers

SAP structures AI for Sales & Service Cloud V2 across three complementary layers ‚Äì where Joule Premium for CX accommodates both premium embedded AI and CX AI toolkit use cases. Together, they enable 30+ AI capabilities, each optimized for a specific class of problems and business outcomes.  See examples below, connected to the main AI focus:

 

Base AI ‚Äî Predictive & Classification Intelligence

Base AI focuses on machine learning‚Äìdriven insights such as prediction, classification, recommendation, and language processing. These capabilities are embedded into Sales and Service Cloud and are available without additional licensing complexity.

Core Base AI Capabilities:

For Sales ScenariosFor Service ScenariosCross-functional Scenarios
  •  Lead & Deal Intelligence (scoring and prioritization)
  • Product Recommendation
  • Business Interaction Intelligence
  • Business Text Intelligence
  • Case Categorization
  • Case Type Determination
  • Similar Case Recommendation
  • Case Topic Analyzer
  • NLP Classification (including sentiment analysis use cases)
  • Profanity Check
  • Machine Translation

 

üí°When Base AI is the right choice - Use Base AI when the problem is repeatable, data-driven, and benefits from historical patterns. It delivers fast ROI with minimal disruption and strong explainability.

 

Embedded Premium AI ‚Äî Generative Productivity Inside CRM

Embedded Premium AI introduces generative intelligence directly into CRM objects in both Sales & Services business objects, transforming structured and unstructured data into concise summaries, insights, and written content.

Core Embedded Premium AI Capabilities

For Sales ScenariosFor Service ScenariosCross-functional Scenarios
    • Account Synopsis
    • Sales Order Summary
    • Survey Trend Summary
    • Lead Booster
    • Email Draft Recommender
  • Case Summary
  • Registered Product Summary
  • Business Information Extraction
  • Email Draft Recommender
  • Utilities Insights
  • Duplicate Check

 

üí°When Embedded Premium AI is the right choice
Use it when speed, productivity, and cognitive load reduction are the primary goals -  especially for frontline sales and service users.

 

CX AI Toolkit ‚Äî Generative, Custom, and Agentic AI

The CX AI Toolkit is where AI becomes configurable, extensible, and increasingly autonomous. It allows organizations to connect AI to enterprise data, define their own use cases, and move beyond assistance toward execution.

Core CX AI Toolkit Capabilities: 

Knowledge & Generative AIAutonomous AI Agents Extensibility
  • Intelligent Q&A
  • Smart Actions
  • Intelligent Customer Profile
  • Autonomous AI Agents 
  • Case Classification Agent
  •  Q&A Agent
  • Quote Creation Agent (Only available for V1 for now, though a similar agent is part of the new & coming set of Agents for V2)
  • Digital Service Agent
  • Knowledge Creation Agent
  • AI Tools (sales & service content tools as one capability area)
  • Custom Tool Builder
  • Custom Agent Builder

 

üí°When the Toolkit is the right choice
Use it when AI must span multiple steps, integrate enterprise knowledge, or act autonomously rather than simply recommend.

 

Business Process - AI Across the Sales and Service v2 Lifecycle

Across lead management, opportunity execution, visits, and order handling, SAP provides a broad set of AI capabilities tightly aligned to sales processes.

Example of Sales Process powered by SAP Business AI:

Key outcomes include:

  • Predictive prioritization of leads and opportunities
  • Faster and better-informed account preparation
  • AI-generated discovery questions and follow-up emails
  • Survey-driven insights for visit planning
  • Automated quote handling through AI Agents

That said, and as illustrated in the picture above, Sales Cloud V2 evolves from a tracking system into a decision-support and execution assistant.

Regarding Service Cloud V2 applies AI across intake, understanding, resolution, and knowledge creation, reducing both handling time and customer effort.

Example of Service Process powered by SAP Business AI

Key outcomes include:

  • Automated categorization and routing of incoming cases
  • Instant understanding through summaries of long interaction histories
  • Faster resolution using similar-case intelligence
  • Entity extraction from unstructured emails and documents
  • Continuous growth of the knowledge base through AI Agents

That said, and as illustrated in the picture above, Service Cloud v2 moves from reactive ticket handling to proactive resolution orchestration.

Intelligent Q&A: The Foundation of Trustworthy AI

Intelligent Q&A, powered by RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation), is one of the core building blocks behind the 30+ AI use cases in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2. In simple terms, it allows people ‚Äî and AI Agents ‚Äî to ask questions in plain language and get answers backed by real CRM data and enterprise documents, with source references for transparency. 

Sometimes customers notice that answers vary in quality. That‚Äôs usually because of how RAG works under the hood: the system looks for the most relevant pieces of information across indexed files, emails, tickets, and product data, and then asks the LLM to generate a grounded answer. The model is probabilistic, so answers can change slightly from one attempt to the next, even when grounded in the same data.

See details about the flow in the image below:

In practice, results get better when the indexed content is well structured (e.g., clean text-based documents). With that in mind, questions that ask for guidance or clarification (e.g., ‚Äúhow to‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat is the policy‚Ä¶‚Äù) tend to produce the most accurate answers.
Examples include resolving an issue, understanding a process, or checking a product policy. On the other hand, requests that ask for summaries, counts, or cross-object overviews don‚Äôt perform as well, such as asking for opportunity summaries or ticket totals.

At a higher level, Intelligent Q&A gives organizations something essential: AI that can be explained, audited, and trusted by CIOs, architects, and compliance teams ‚Äî which is why it‚Äôs such a critical foundation for enterprise AI.

From Assistance to Autonomy: The New Role of CX AI Agents

SAP‚Äôs CX AI Agents are moving customer experience from ‚ÄúAI that assists humans‚Äù to ‚ÄúAI that performs routine work autonomously‚Äù ‚Äî all while staying connected to SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 data, business logic, and governance.

Instead of generic chatbots, these agents are designed to perform specific enterprise tasks such as classifying tickets, creating knowledge articles, answering product questions, or compiling case information. They combine:

‚úî Continuous context awareness (tickets, emails, catalog, meeting transcripts)
‚úî Task execution using CX AI Toolkit tools and CRM APIs
‚úî Business guardrails (policies, confidence scores, approvals)

Depending on the use case, agents can either assist or fully automate workflows.

Examples of Autonomous & Semi-Autonomous CX Agents

  • Case Classification Agent ‚Üí categorizes incoming cases based on business rules
  • Knowledge Creation Agent ‚Üí generates KBAs from new tickets
  • Digital Service Agent ‚Üí responds to common inquiries in natural language
  • Q&A Agent ‚Üí answers operational questions using CRM, ticket, or product data
  • Custom AI Agents ‚Üí automate organization-specific tasks using custom prompts and tools

This model doesn‚Äôt eliminate humans ‚Äî it shifts them toward value work, while AI handles:

  • First-level inquiries
  • Case enrichment & categorization
  • Article creation
  • Data retrieval & validation
  • Repetitive information lookups

Human-in-the-Loop by Design

When confidence is low or approvals are required, the agent automatically escalates. This ensures:

  • Control over sensitive actions
  • Transparency on data sources
  • Trust for compliance & audit teams

The long-term outcome is not human replacement, but:

  • Fewer manual clicks
  • Faster resolutions
  • Better customer responses
  • Higher productivity for sales & service teams

As organizations add custom prompts and tools, CX AI Agents become an orchestration layer between enterprise data, SAP applications, and human expertise, supporting a realistic pathway toward automation in Sales & Service Cloud V2.

Adoption Guidance ‚Äì Matching Business Needs to the Right AI Use Case

 

Examples of lenses and guidance to consider‚Äã:

Or rather, a simple and defensible adoption lens could be :

  • Base AI ‚Üí Prediction, scoring, and classification
  • Embedded Premium AI ‚Üí Summaries, narratives, productivity acceleration
  • CX AI Toolkit & Agents ‚Üí Automation, autonomy, and customization

The objective is not ‚Äúmore AI‚Äù, but clear value, no overlap, and controlled total cost of ownership.

Furthermore, there are several assets available that can support you, provide adoption guidance, and inform your decision-making. Please see below:

  • Joule Premium Adoption Playbook for SAP Sales and Service Cloud (More CX AI toolkit capabilities focused)
  • Mastering the AI Mindset - Co-Creating the Future of AI & Customer Experience with SAP CX
  • The Art of Possible: Why Now Is the Time for SAP Sales and Service AI Agents in Customer Experience
  • AI Value Calculator - Calculate your potential savings
  • PUMP Package ‚Äì SAP Joule Premium for Customer Experience
  • SAP Business AI estimator

Agentic AI - What‚Äôs Coming Next

Agentic AI in SAP Sales Cloud v2: Join the Customer Engagement Initiative

See more HERE.

And also, roadmap explorer HERE.

Final Takeaway: AI as a CRM Operating Model

SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 now delivers:

  • 30+ AI capabilities available today
  • A clear progression from insight ‚Üí productivity ‚Üí autonomy
  • A trusted AI foundation aligned with enterprise governance

For consultants, architects, CIOs, and business leaders, this is no longer an innovation discussion. It is an operating model decision that defines how customer-facing teams work at scale. Organizations that adopt AI intentionally will not just work faster ‚Äî they will work smarter, with less friction and more impact.

Thank you for reading, and please don't hesitate to reach out if you need any support.

entry.content:
Hello team,

In order to check cost calculation we encourage you to check with your SAP sales representative to send you a quotation based on your specific SAP licensing conditions.  

Cost calculation for a system is complex and depends on what you consider, as you can only count the License, or you can count the host, number of CPU resources, Database, memory space, etc. 

Check as well https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-focused-run/expert-portal/focused-run-faq.html?anchorId=section 
What do I need to do if I need support with the SAP Focused Run licensing metric calculation for my particular situation?

Please contact us under the following email address FocusedRun@sap.com .

Regards,

Luis Salazar

entry.title: SAP Data Services, generated ABAP DF program can not be transported with variables!!
entry.content:
hello experts,

I try to generate an ABAP program related to an ABAP Dataflow, the DF uses a global variable (or a parameter) => Upload Ok.

I try to release the CR in SAP S/4HANA 2021 system => CR releasae Ok.

When I transport there are errors related to how the Global variables or parameters in ABAP dataflow are translated in PARAMETER $PARAM# in ABAP program (# = 1,2,3... positional parameter identifier).

So during STMS transport of a generated ABAP program from an ABAP dataflow, a check on ABAP consistency is made (parameters needs to start with literals or '_').
By default the code generated by SAP DS contains the '$' symbol as first character.

This prevent of transporting any ABAP dataflow that is using Gobal variables or Parameters.

There is no workaround or mention in SAP Help (tested an export of PDF and query to notebooklm),

I can't find any workaround in SAP notes.

 

This limitation prevent the usage of "Execute Preloaded" with SAP S/4 or SAP ECC production datastore, as the ABAP programs can not be transported beccause of '$' issue, and with closed client we can not directly or manually upload these programs to S/4HANA productive tenant.

So the only workaround I found is open the client to changes and use "Generate and Execute" with a productive S/4HANA system.

 

Do you have any workaround?

best regards,

Alberto

entry.title: Re: Complete Guide: Setting Up CAP Plugin for Advanced Event Mesh with OAuth Authentication
entry.content:
Hello @Fiona_Zhang_FZ 
Not out of the box, no.

The advanced-event-mesh plugin looks for service-instances and they must be available in the same org/space the application is running in.

The only chance you have is to "patch" the advanced-event-mesh plugin and make it work via User-Provided Services:

const _getCredsFromVcap = test => {
  const vcap = process.env.VCAP_SERVICES && JSON.parse(process.env.VCAP_SERVICES)
  if (!vcap) throw new Error('No VCAP_SERVICES in process environment')
  // Node-Patch -> allow to iterate user-provded services
  for (const binding in vcap) {
    for (const instance of vcap[binding]) {
      if (test(instance)) return instance.credentials
    }
  }
  /*
  for (const name in vcap) {
    const srv = vcap[name][0]
    if (test(srv)) return srv.credentials
  }
  */
}

And:

const _validateBroker = async (mgmt_uri, subaccountId) => {
  // via VCAP_SERVICES to avoid specifying _another_ cds.requires service
  // * Node-Patch -> allow for user-provided services with a specific tag
  const creds = _getCredsFromVcap(srv => (srv.plan === 'aem-validation-service-plan' || srv.tags?.includes('aem-validation-service')))
// ...
}

Doing so, you could:
- Create mandatory service-instances in the Global Account where AEM is provisioned
- Copy them over to the other Global Account as User-Provided Services

But his is kinda hacky and requires you to change the original coding of the CAP Plugin (meaning, you need to take care about upgrades, changes, fixes, etc...).


Best,
R.

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite Workflows with Job Scheduling Service üöÄ
entry.content:
Schedule Your SAP Integration Suite Workflows with Job Scheduling Service ‚Äì Secured with JWT Authentication! üîêüöÄ

Are you using SAP Integration Suite? You may be wondering is it possible to use the SAP Job Scheduling service to start integrations on a timely matter.

I was wondering the same. And the answer is YES! You can use the SAP Job Scheduling service to trigger integrations in the Integration Suite. But how?

To achieve this, you need to expose your integration as an HTTP endpoint. This can be done by creating API in the Integration Suite's API Management - this will allow your workflow to be triggered via HTTP requests. Ok this is something trivial for Integration Suite users.

But now to ensure that only the SAP Job Scheduling service can trigger your integration? In your API setup you need to implement authentication mechanisms - verify that the token coming from the Job Scheduling service is valid. For this, you can use verifyJWT policy. And that's it!

Now let's show it step by step.

For more cool Job Scheduling Service Blog Posts check the Overview page

Prerequisites

For my setup I have used the BTP Trial account + followed some SAP Tutorials to get a workflow and API up and running.

  1. Get an Account on SAP BTP Trial
  2. Set Up Integration Suite Trial
  3. Design and Deploy Your First Integration Flow
  4. Expose Integration Flow Endpoint as API and Test the Flow

With this done you get an endpoint that can be triggered via HTTP request. But beware because this endpoint is public - anyone knowing the URL can trigger it.

Create Job Scheduling Service Instance

Now let's create a Job Scheduling service instance that will be used to trigger our Integration Suite API on a schedule.

Using BTP Cockpit

  1. Navigate to your BTP Trial Subaccount
  2. Go to Services ‚Üí Service Marketplace
  3. Search for Job Scheduling Service (or jobscheduler)
  4. Click on the service tile
  5. Click Create button
  6. Fill in the instance details:
    • Service: Job Scheduling Service
    • Plan: Select free (or standard in BTP Production)
    • Runtime Environment: Cloud Foundry
    • Space: dev if you are using trial (or your space name for BTP Production)
    • Instance Name: jobscheduler-integration-suite (or any name you prefer)
  7. Click Create (no need to add parrameters)

Using CF CLI

Alternatively, you can use the Cloud Foundry CLI:

cf create-service jobscheduler free jobscheduler-integration-suite

Wait for the service instance to be created. You can check the status with:

cf service jobscheduler-integration-suite

Once the service is created, you can access the Job Scheduling service dashboard through the BTP Cockpit by clicking on your service instance and selecting View Dashboard.

Create a Job in Job Scheduling Service that Triggers the Integration

Now that we have both the Job Scheduling service instance and the Integration Suite API endpoint, let's create a job that will trigger the integration on a schedule.

Step 1: Get Your Integration API Endpoint URL

From the Integration Suite API Management, you need to get the full URL of your API endpoint. Go to Configure -> APIs and then choose your API. Inside you can find your API Proxy URL.

Make sure to copy this URL - you'll need it in the next step.

Step 2: Open the Job Scheduling Dashboard

  1. Navigate to your BTP Trial Subaccount
  2. Go to Services ‚Üí Instances and Subscriptions
  3. Find your Job Scheduling service instance (jobscheduler-integration-suite)
  4. Click on the instance name
  5. Click View Dashboard button

Note: You may need to log in with your BTP credentials when accessing the dashboard for the first time.

Step 3: Create a Job

  1. In the Job Scheduling dashboard, click Jobs from the left-hand menu
  2. Click the Create Job button
  3. Fill in the job details:
    • Name: Trigger Integration Flow (or any meaningful name)
    • Description: Triggers the Integration Suite API endpoint
    • Action: Paste your Integration API Proxy URL (from Step 1) + add /details
    • HTTP Method: Select POST (as we follow the tutorial)
  4. Click Save

Note: After saving, you'll see a warning icon next to the job. This is normal - it means the job needs a schedule to actually run.

Step 4: Create a Schedule

  1. Click on the job name you just created to open its details
  2. From the left-hand menu, click Schedules
  3. Click Create Schedule button
  4. Configure the schedule:
    • Pattern: Leave One Time
    • Value: Enter now
    • Data: Add your payload, if you have followed the previous tutorial to create an integration that expects a payload:
    {
  "productIdentifier": "HT-2000"
}
  5. Click Save

Step 5: Verify the Job Execution

  1. After saving the schedule, click on the schedule description to view its details
  2. From the left-hand menu, select Run Logs
  3. Wait for the scheduled time to pass (or if you used now as the pattern, it should execute immediately)
  4. Refresh the page to see the execution results
  5. You should see a status of COMPLETED with a green checkmark if successful

Click on the Run Log ID to see detailed information about the execution, including:

  • HTTP status code received from your Integration endpoint
  • Response body
  • Execution timestamp
  • Duration

Success! - without security yet.

At this point, your job is successfully calling the Integration Suite API endpoint. However, this endpoint is still publicly accessible - anyone with the URL can trigger it. In the next section, we'll secure it so that only the Job Scheduling service can call it.

Secure the Integration Endpoint

To ensure that only the Job Scheduling Service can trigger your integration, you need to implement JWT (JSON Web Token) authentication in your API using Integration Suite's API Management policies.

The Job Scheduling service automatically sends a JWT token in the Authorization header when calling your endpoint. We'll configure the API to verify this token, ensuring only legitimate calls from your Job Scheduler instance are accepted.

Reference: This section is inspired by Part 1: Modeling the JWT token verification flows in SAP Cloud Platform API Management

Understanding the JWT Verification Flow

The verification process involves these steps:

  1. Fetch JWKS from XSUAA - Get them from the Job Scheduler's XSUAA service /token_keys
  2. Get the public certificate - to verify the JWT signature
  3. Verify JWT token - Validate the incoming token using the public certificate and check claims like issuer and audience.

Note: we will not include caching for this example to keep it simple

Step 1: Get Your Job Scheduler Service Key

First, you need to get the XSUAA credentials from your Job Scheduling service instance.

  1. Navigate to your BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount ‚Üí Spaces
  2. Go to Services ‚Üí Instances
  3. Find your jobscheduler-integration-suite instance
  4. Click on the instance, then go to Service Keys
  5. Click Create to create a new service key (name it api-integration-key)
  6. Click on the service key to view its JSON content

You'll need these values from the service key:

  • uaa.url: The XSUAA server URL (e.g., https://dadb4adetrial.authentication.ap21.hana.ondemand.com)
  • uaa.clientid: The application name (e.g., sb-377fab0e-30b1-49e2-8632-01968ee8d436!b97749|sap-jobscheduler!b4)

The information about the token can be found on {uaa.url}/.well-known/openid-configuration

The JWKS endpoint URL will be: {uaa.url}/token_keys. It contains the public keys needed to verify the JWT tokens.

Step 2: Open Your API in Integration Suite

  1. Navigate to Integration Suite ‚Üí Configure ‚Üí APIs
  2. Select your API that you created in the prerequisites

 

  1. Click on Policies to open the Policy Editor
  2. Click Edit to enter edit mode
 

Step 3: Add JWT Verification Policies

We'll add 4 policies in the ProxyEndpoint ‚Üí PreFlow section (these run before your integration is called):

3.1 Add Service Callout Policy

This policy fetches the JWKS from XSUAA if they're not in cache.

  1. Click the + button next to Service Callout (under Extension Policies)

  2. Name it: readJWKS

  3. Click Add

  4. Replace the policy content with (update the URL with your {uaa.url}/token_keys endpoint from above):

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<ServiceCallout async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Response>JWTKeys</Response>
    <Timeout>30000</Timeout>
    <HTTPTargetConnection>
        <URL>your.uaa.url/token_keys</URL>
    </HTTPTargetConnection>
</ServiceCallout>

Important: Replace the URL with your actual XSUAA token_keys endpoint from Step 1.

3.2 Extract Public Certificates

In this step, we extract the public keys from the JWKS response. So that it can be used later in the JWT verification.

Why is this the step needed? Because the response from the token_keys endpoint may contains different fields and we need exactly the public keys.

  1. Click the + button next to Extract Variables (under Message Policies)
  2. Name it: extractPublicKeys
  3. Click Add
  4. Replace the policy content with:
<ExtractVariables xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt" async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true">
<Source>JWTKeys.content</Source>
  <JSONPayload>
    <!-- Pull the PEM from the "value" field -->
    <Variable name="PUBLIC_KEY_PEM">
      <JSONPath>$.keys[0].value</JSONPath>
    </Variable>
  </JSONPayload>
  <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
</ExtractVariables>

3.3 Add Verify JWT Policy

This is the main policy that validates the JWT token from Job Scheduler.

  1. Click the + button next to Verify JWT (under Security Policies)
  2. Name it: verifyJWT
  3. Click Add
  4. Replace the policy content with (update the issuer):
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<VerifyJWT async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Algorithm>RS256</Algorithm>
    <PublicKey>
        <Value ref="PUBLIC_KEY_PEM"/>
    </PublicKey>
    <Issuer>your.uaa.url/oauth/token</Issuer>
    <Audience>uaa.clientid</Audience>
</VerifyJWT>

Important:

  • Update <Issuer> with your XSUAA URL + /oauth/token
  • Update <Audience> with your clientid from the service key
  • These values must match exactly or the token verification will fail

Step 4: Save and Deploy

  1. Click Update in the Policy Editor to save all policies
  2. Click Save to persist the API changes
  3. Click Deploy to deploy the updated API
  4. The API is now protected with JWT authentication!

Step 5: Understanding the Policy Flow

Here's what happens when Job Scheduler calls your API:

1. Job Scheduler ‚Üí API (with JWT token in Authorization header)
2. readJWKS ‚Üí Fetches JWKS from XSUAA
3. extractPublicKeys ‚Üí Extracts public key from JWKS into variable
4. verifyJWT ‚Üí Validates JWT token with JWKS
5. IF valid ‚Üí Integration Flow executes
6. IF invalid ‚Üí Returns 401 Unauthorized

Testing the Secured Integration

Now let's test that the JWT verification is working correctly.

Test 1: Job Scheduler Should Succeed

  1. Go back to the Job Scheduling Dashboard
  2. Navigate to your job and schedule
  3. Manually trigger the one time job by activating it (or wait for the next scheduled run if the job is recurring)
  4. Check the Run Logs
  5. You should see COMPLETED status with HTTP 200

This proves that Job Scheduler can successfully authenticate with the JWT token.

Test 2: Direct API Call Should Fail

To verify the security is working, try calling the API directly without a valid token:

  1. In Integration Suite, go to your API
  2. Click on Test tab
  3. Try to call the API without authorization
  4. You should receive a 401 Unauthorized response

Or test with curl:

curl -X POST "https://your-api-url.com/your-integration-path" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"productIdentifier": "HT-2000"}'

Expected error response:

{
  "fault": {
    "faultstring": "Failed to Resolve Variable : policy(verifyJWT) variable(null)",
    "detail": { "errorcode": "steps.jwt.FailedToResolveVariable" }
  }
}

Test 3: Wrong Job Scheduler Instance Should Fail

If you have multiple Job Scheduling service instances, try calling from a different instance:

  1. Create a job in a different Job Scheduler instance
  2. Point it to the same Integration API endpoint
  3. Run the job
  4. Check the Run Logs - you should see REQUEST_ERROR (401)

Expected error from a different Job Scheduler instance:

{
  "fault": {
    "faultstring": "Invalid Claim: policy(verifyJWT) claim(aud)",
    "detail": {
      "errorcode": "steps.jwt.InvalidClaim"
    }
  }
}

This happens because the audience claim in the JWT token doesn't match the one configured in your verifyJWT policy, proving that only your specific Job Scheduler instance can trigger the integration.

Conclusion

Congratulations! üéâ You've successfully:

  1. ‚úÖCreated a Job Scheduling service instance in BTP
  2. ‚úÖConfigured a job to trigger your Integration Suite API endpoint on a schedule
  3. ‚úÖSecured the API endpoint using JWT token verification
  4. ‚úÖEnsured only your specific Job Scheduler instance can call the integration

What You've Learned

  • How to integrate SAP Job Scheduling Service with Integration Suite APIs
  • How to implement JWT-based authentication in API Management
  • How to use JWKS for token verification with caching
  • How the JWT verification flow works in Integration Suite

Key Takeaways

  • Automatic Authentication: Job Scheduler automatically sends JWT tokens - no additional configuration needed in the job
  • Strong Security: The audience claim ensures only your specific service instance can access the API
  • Zero Trust: Even if someone knows your API URL, they can't call it without a valid JWT token from your Job Scheduler

Next Steps

Consider these enhancements:

  • Add more schedules: Create recurring schedules (hourly, daily, weekly)
  • Monitor executions: Use the Job Scheduler dashboard to track success rates
  • Handle errors: Implement error handling in your integration flow
  • Alert on failures: Use SAP Alert Notification service for failed job runs
  • Add logging: Enhance your integration flow with detailed logging for troubleshooting
  • Custom claims: Add additional JWT claim validation (e.g., scope, client_id)

Troubleshooting

Problem: "Invalid token" error

Symptoms: Job shows REQUEST_ERROR (401) with message about invalid token

Possible Causes & Solutions:

  1. JWKS URL is incorrect

    • Check the readJWKS Service Callout policy
    • Verify the URL ends with /token_keys
    • Ensure it matches your XSUAA domain from the service key

  2. Issuer mismatch

    • Check the <Issuer> in your verifyJWT policy
    • Must match: {uaa.url}/oauth/token
    • Case-sensitive!

  3. Audience mismatch

    • Check the <Audience> in your verifyJWT policy
    • Must match the clientid from your Job Scheduler service key
    • Example: sb-377fab0e-30b1-49e2-8632-01968ee8d436!b97749|sap-jobscheduler!b4

Problem: FailedToResolveVariable error

Symptoms: Job shows REQUEST_ERROR (401) with message "Failed to Resolve Variable"

{"fault":"{faultstring":"Failed to Resolve Variable : policy(verifyJWT)
variable(JWTKeys.content)',"detail": {"errorcode":"steps.jwt.FailedToResolveVariable"}}}

Possible Causes:

If you decide to include caching for the JWKS, this error may occur if the cache contains old and invalid data.

Possible Solutions

In verifyJWT put the directly Public Key instead of JWKS ref or remove the caching policies to simplify the flow.

Instead of

<PublicKey>
        <Value ref="PUBLIC_KEY_PEM"/>
</PublicKey>

it can be changed the value of keys.[0].value of {uaa.url}/token_keys

<PublicKey>
<Value>
    		-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----
    		MIIBIjANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ8AMIIBCgKCAQEArwaPuBnCZqghcYY+x8RA
    		qUSC/NwE2aflfyRvDT+9P7gCjQiXz+RxqQ7Mh4RL41jANIMr9m3TeUFOjuitY9En
    		K3i4qTBrWNvsTdx/NdL9OOx55O4DMVOeANEtxXhrfDDMb7iRDFsfNmgPn06iIc2C
    		example - do not copy
    		5wYN2cMO4Ne1GFZmtduz2WEEwnWU4/6+ie8ONIGO52DJPXIqHk2d4SRAjLaTDzSx
    		a/iBVSmlSLbWmhSFcUHkMkX3BkEdG6A2tmRFwyEv1e3jQ+1+Q+wekr538I3nwATp
    		xQIDAQAB
    		-----END PUBLIC KEY-----
</Value>
</PublicKey>

This is not recommended for production but can help to identify the problem.

Problem: "Invalid Claim: claim(aud)" error

Symptoms: Different Job Scheduler instance gets 401 with audience claim error

Solution: This is expected! The audience validation ensures only your specific Job Scheduler instance can call the API. If you need multiple instances to access it, you'd need to:

  • Add multiple <Audience> elements in the policy

Problem: Job shows COMPLETED but integration didn't run

Possible Causes & Solutions:

  1. Check API routing: Ensure the API proxy is properly routing to your integration flow
  2. Check integration flow status: Verify it's deployed and running in Integration Suite
  3. Review integration logs: Check the integration flow monitoring for errors

Debug API

Inside the Integration Suite you can check the API calls in the Test ‚Üí Debug section:

  1. Navigate to your API in Integration Suite
  2. Go to Test tab
  3. Enable Debug Session
  4. Trigger a call from Job Scheduler
  5. Review the debug trace to see:
    • Which policies executed
    • JWT token validation results
    • Request/response headers and body

This is extremely helpful for understanding what's happening at each step of the policy flow.

Additional Resources

    • SAP Job Scheduling Service Documentation
    • SAP Integration Suite API Management
    • JWT Policy Reference
    • Blog Series: JWT verification using SAP Cloud Platform API Management

 

For more cool Job Scheduling Service Blog Posts check the Overview page

Happy Scheduling! üöÄ

entry.title: Joule with SAP Signavio Is Now GA: Your Conversational Gateway to Process Transformation
entry.content:
We‚Äôve got exciting news to share: Joule with SAP Signavio solutions* is now generally available.

After months of successful collaboration with customers in our Early Adopter Care (EAC) program, this launch marks a major step towards delivering a conversational experience making it easier than ever to explore, understand, manage and transform your processes with SAP Signavio solutions.

In this blog, we‚Äôll dive into the world of Joule with SAP Signavio, exploring real-world examples of how Joule can be leveraged to quickly access information, navigate process assets, and execute actions with ease. We‚Äôll discuss why Joule‚Äôs integration across SAP applications matters and the strategic evolution to advanced agentic AI capabilities.

Finally, we will provide indications on how to activate Joule in SAP Signavio, so that you can get started straight away!

Joule with SAP Signavio solutions

What is Joule

Joule is an AI solution that helps teams act with clarity and collaborate without silos. It turns siloed data and tasks into intelligent, connected workflows that help improve decisions, speed up end-to-end processes, and create a unified AI experience across SAP and non-SAP systems. With AI agents for all core functions, powered by SAP business process expertise, your AI strategy scales faster and wider. 

Inside SAP Signavio, Joule becomes your process companion, helping you navigate, analyze and manage your processes through natural language.

The unique value? Deep process context from SAP Signavio combined with orchestration across SAP applications, including but not limited to SAP S/4HANA, SAP BTP, and SAP SuccessFactors.

Joule offers a seamless user experience across SAP and non-SAP systems allowing employees to ask questions and interact with Joule from anywhere. While working in SAP Signavio, users can interact with data and capabilities from other systems and/or while in other systems, they can access SAP Signavio capabilities. 

How Joule with SAP Signavio Helps You Work Smarter 

Now generally available, Joule with SAP Signavio delivers over 50 skills across three use cases - Informational, Navigational, and Transactional ‚Äì with additional Analytical capabilities planned for future releases. 

These interaction patterns are designed to simplify your day-to-day tasks.

  • Informational: Joule acts as an intelligent assistant, helping users understand how to perform specific tasks or generating a textual comparison between processes. For example, you can ask Joule: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the difference between draft and published process models?‚Äù or ‚ÄúHow can I set up a dashboard?‚Äù
  • Navigational:  Joule simplifies content navigation across SAP Signavio solutions and guides users through the SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub to access various assets such as process and journey models, and value accelerators. For example, you can ask Joule: ‚ÄúOpen the Order-to-Cash process model published for EMEA‚Äù or ‚ÄúFind accelerators for the Financial Process‚Äù
  • Transactional: Joule enables users to perform actions conversationally, such as creating and deleting assets within the SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite, including processes, journey models, and dictionary items. For example, you can tell Joule: ‚ÄúCreate a new dictionary term and link it to the Returns process.‚Äù or ‚ÄúDelete the journey model called Sales Process‚Äù

Find here the full list of Joule skills in SAP Signavio.

A Real-World Example 

Imagine you're an end-user exploring the SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub. You want to learn more about a specific process documented in SAP Signavio‚Äîlet‚Äôs say the "Order to Cash" process..  

  • You can ask Joule: ‚ÄúWho is the process owner of the Order to cash process?‚Äù ‚Üí Joule skills suggest the process that most closely matches your query and retrieve the owner information from the diagram attributes. 
  • You can then ask Joule: ‚ÄúProvide me with a description of the process flow‚Äù ‚Üí  Joule skills convert the process visual into a clear process description.

Moreover, as an end-user, you may want to identify discrepancies between two different process models, in our example ‚ÄúProcure to Pay ‚Äì Global" and ‚ÄúProcure to Pay ‚Äì EU‚Äù.

  • You can ask Joule: ‚ÄúCompare process models ‚ÄúProcure to Pay ‚Äì Global‚Äù with ‚ÄúProcure to Pay ‚Äì EU‚Äù   ‚Üí Joule skills provide a textual summary which highlights the key differences between the two process models.

What used to take hours now happens in minutes - through a simple conversation.

Why Joule Across SAP Applications Matters  

Joule isn‚Äôt limited to SAP Signavio. It works across SAP applications**.  That means: 

  • One unified AI experience: Joule works across SAP applications including, amongst others, SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP BTP. This means that SAP Signavio process context and intelligence is now accessible to the user across all Joule-compatible applications.
  • Process-aware orchestration:  Joule does not just answer questions, but it understands and can orchestrate actions and recommendations.
  • Responsible AI: Responsible AI at SAP is based on three pillars: ethics, security, and compliance. Joule provides grounded answers and governance for enterprise trust, as it‚Äôs built on enterprise-grade AI, and can safely operate at the heart of your business. Process ownership and access are respected, and AI can be scaled confidently across your processes.   

Joule Agents for SAP Signavio

SAP is developing Joule Agents embedded into every business function and accessed with role-based assistants. They use SAP‚Äôs process expertise to automate complex workflows and deliver AI value at scale.

Joule Agents for SAP Signavio solutions can help you accelerate content discovery and process analysis, create value cases and enhance user onboarding.

Five Joule Agents for SAP Signavio are now available as part of a dedicated beta program:

  • Dashboard Analyzer Agent explains insights and drives process improvements in SAP Signavio.
  • Process Content Recommender Agent intelligently recommends relevant process content in SAP Signavio.
  • Screen Guide Agent accelerates understanding and adoption of SAP Signavio
  • Value Case Creation Agent turns process insights into actionable value cases in SAP Signavio
  • Workspace Administration Agent onboards new process experts quickly in SAP Signavio.

Overview of the Process Content Recommender Agent 

To learn more about Joule Agents for SAP Signavio solutions and our beta program, read here.

 How to Activate Joule in SAP Signavio 

Visit this page to learn how to activate Joule Base in your environment.

Learn more about Joule

To learn more about Joule and Joule  with SAP Signavio solutions check the following additional resources:

  • Joule in SAP Signavio Help Portal
  • SAP Discovery Center AI Feature - SAP Signavio solutions, Joule
  • REGISTER NOW: SAP Joule Agents in SAP Signavio Bet... - SAP Community

 

*Joule is currently not available in SAP Signavio Process Insights or SAP Signavio Process Governance.

**To enable this unified experience, the right connections must be set up. Learn more: Joule - Unified Setup: Bridging Simplicity and Per... - SAP Community 

Any thoughts or questions? Please share any feedback or thoughts in a comment.

entry.title: Vision AI in Tricentis: UI automation that sees like we do
entry.content:
Context

UI automation doesn‚Äôt break because teams are doing it wrong. It breaks because UI surfaces move all the time: layouts shift, IDs change, components get refactored, themes evolve‚Ä¶ and suddenly your ‚Äúreliable‚Äù selector-based tests spend more time in maintenance than in delivery.

Two consequences show up fast:

  • Fragility: tests keep failing for reasons unrelated to the business flow
  • Speed & effort: automation arrives late, and when it arrives it‚Äôs expensive to maintain

What Vision AI is?

Vision AI is a testing engine in the Tricentis ecosystem, comparable to XScan.
It combines deep convolutional neural networks with advanced heuristics to recognize UI controls visually and keep them trackable even when the application changes. The result is stable, self-healing, platform-agnostic UI automation.

What changes with Vision AI

Instead of relying mainly on technical identifiers, Vision AI focuses on what‚Äôs actually on screen and how it behaves. Concretely, this brings three benefits without repeating the same story twice:

  • More resilient automation when the UI changes (less ‚Äúlocator firefighting‚Äù)
  • Works across technologies (legacy, virtual desktops, web, desktop - mixed landscapes)
  • Earlier automation (you can start from mockups or early UI designs and refine as the app evolves)

Real-time object tracking

One of the most convincing capabilities is real-time object tracking: Vision AI can track controls on any technology while the application is running : recognizing fields, buttons, dialogs, lists, and state changes as the screen updates.

That‚Äôs why the demo format works so well: an application screen with an overlay showing detected controls, like an augmented layer on top of the UI.

One approach, multiple formats 

To make the ‚Äúplatform-agnostic‚Äù point tangible, it helps to show the same intent across different front-ends:

  • PDF mockup (early design / form layout)
  • Windows application (thick client UI)
  • Web page (browser UI)

The goal isn‚Äôt to claim they‚Äôre technically identical. It‚Äôs to show that from an automation perspective, Vision AI can apply a consistent interaction approach because it relies on what‚Äôs visible and interactable.

Vision Script

To operationalize this at scale:

  • Vision Script is the language used to write test cases executed by the Vision AI Executor.
  • From Tosca, you run it using the Run VisionScript module.

What‚Äôs next: Tosca Agentic Test Automation 

Vision AI is a strong foundation, because once the system can consistently understand what‚Äôs on screen, the next logical move is to reduce the effort of creating and maintaining tests.

On the roadmap for Q2 2026, Tricentis is heading toward agentic test automation, with a focus on making test authoring more accessible and faster:

  • Generate test cases from natural language
  • AI-assisted authoring leveraging Microsoft Azure OpenAI
  • Two interaction modes: Co-creation (review and confirm each step before execution) or Autonomous (generate and run end-to-end flows with minimal input)

More details will come as the feature set matures, this is just the direction of travel (and it‚Äôs a promising one!).

Conclusion & next steps

Vision AI makes UI automation more resilient: less locator firefighting, less maintenance, and more consistent execution across enterprise UI technologies. And because it can reliably ‚Äúunderstand‚Äù what‚Äôs on screen, it naturally opens the door to Agentic Automation.

I‚Äôll share updates and real examples as it evolves. Follow my posts to stay informed. More to come!

entry.title: How to populate Sales Office in CO-PA: Derivation & Realignment
entry.content:
Introduction:

A common issue arises when the Sales Office field remains blank in profitability segments despite being active in the configuration. This occurs because the derivation path from the Sales and Distribution (SD) documents to CO-PA has not been established. This guide outlines how to configure derivation rules for future orders and how to use realignments to fix existing data.

Technical Solution:

1. Set Up Characteristic Derivation (KEDR)

To ensure future Sales Orders capture the Sales Office, you must create a link between the Sales Header table (VBAK) and your CO-PA characteristic.

To do so, Go to T-Code KEDR

Click on ‚ÄúCreate Step‚Äù button as shown below,

Select ‚ÄúTable lookup‚Äù radio button as shown below and press Continue (Enter),

Enter the table name as shown below, in our case it is ‚ÄúVBAK‚Äù and press Continue (Enter)

Enter the Step description as shown below,

In the ‚ÄúAssignment of table Fields to Target Fields‚Äù section, Enter the Technical field name for Sales Office in VBAK and COPA as shown below and Click Save button,

Go back to the main screen , we can find the Derivation that we have maintained

Once the Characteristic Derivation is maintained, Future Sales Orders would automatically derive the Sales Office Field in COPA.

2. Update Existing Data via Realignment (KEND)

Configuring KEDR only affects future postings. To populate the Sales Office for orders already in the system, you must run a Realignment.

To do so, Go to T-Code KEND,

Click on ‚ÄúRealignment Run‚Äù button as shown below,

Enter the Short Text and press Accept as shown below,

Now Select the created Realignment run and Click ‚ÄúRequest‚Äù button to create a request for the realignment run as shown below,

Enter a description for the request and Select ‚ÄúSales Order‚Äù field in ‚ÄúSelection Condition‚Äù Tab and Click the down arrow as Highlighted and shown below,

Enter the Sales Orders for which Realignment process needs to be done as shown below,

Click Back button and come to the main screen,

Select the Realignment run as shown below,

To execute the Realignment Run, Select the menu as shown below,

Below Screen appears asking if it is Test Mode or not, Select Test Mode check box and click Accept Button,

The Status will change from New to Scheduled as Highlighted below,

Go to SM37 and select Scheduled Check box as shown below and click Execute,

Select the Job and Click Release button as shown below,

Select Immediate and Click Continue as shown below,

Click Refresh to see if the Job is completed.

Now Go to KEND, Status Changes from Scheduled to Tested

To perform the actual run, go to the menu again as shown below,

Untick Test Mode check box as shown below and click Accept,

The Status changes from Tested to Scheduled.

Now repeat the steps like Test mode

Go to SM37-> Click Execute-> Select the Job-> Click Release button->Immediate->Save->Refresh

Go back to KEND, the status changes from Scheduled to Successful.

Now go the relevant Sales Order and check if the Sales Office has been derived.

Conclusion:


By properly configuring derivation rules in CO-PA, the system can correctly derive and populate the Sales Office from SD documents during transaction processing. For records already posted without this information, realignment provides an effective way to correct historical profitability segments. Together, these steps ensure accurate, complete CO-PA reporting and prevent missing characteristic values in future and existing data.

I hope this blog helps you understand the link between SD documents and CO-PA and how derivation rules ensure accurate data flow. Feel free to share your feedback or post any questions in the comments section.

entry.title: Re: Two APIs to Retrieve Availability Information
entry.content:
@Bunny 
Sorry, I just saw your question. I guess, this is a misunderstanding. I was not talking about the support of the different stock-types but about temporary reservations. If you e. g. create a sales order the quantities are reserved with a temporary reservation as long as the sales order has not been saved or cancelled. If you use the Info API there are no temporary reservations written as this is a pure check of the availability and two requests will provide the same result.

entry.title: Re: Do the buttons inside SapGuiTextArea on "Create Stand...
entry.content:
These buttons belong to the Textedit Control itself and are completely handled by the control.

If you referred to SAP GUI Scripting events, then the answer is that using these buttons does not cause direct events, but only indirect changes to the content of the Textedit Control (for example when the text is changed by triggering a paste or cut function).

entry.title: How Is Agentic AI in SAP Transforming Core Business Processes Today?
entry.content:
From Deterministic Automation to Agentic Process Execution

Traditional SAP automation operates via predetermined workflows that trigger events under specified circumstances only. Any change from this path necessitated manual actions. The introduction of an intelligent agent into the SAP environment allows for a very different method of operating, in which the agent has the ability to "think", analyze, and resolve problems autonomously.

SAP uses reasoning models and live business context to create AI Agents for SAP. An example of this is an AI agent that monitors the fulfillment of orders. Instead of just flagging an order as delinquent if it is delayed, the AI agent draws on its knowledge of upstream supply constraints and determines whether to re-route inventory or to negotiate new delivery windows with its supplier based on the contractual penalty associated with violating their contract. The logic for making these decisions is not hard-coded; it is inferred from the context surrounding the order.

Additionally, SAP AI supports a feedback-driven execution process whereby each decision made by the AI agent provides a learning opportunity for the next execution cycle. For example, if an agent executes a corrective action that incurs additional costs but does not improve service level performance, it will adjust future decision-making accordingly. This results in a cyclic execution loop as opposed to single-event automation.

Some of the key execution traits include:

  • Goal-oriented reasoning rather than task completion
  • Context-aware evaluation across SAP modules
  • Continuous recalibration based on outcomes

SAP AI Teams designs these agents with explicit governance controls that guide every action. Clearly defined business rules determine what an agent can decide and when escalation is required. Comprehensive audit trails then record the rationale behind each decision, which helps create traceability and accountability. As a result, agent autonomy functions within clearly controlled boundaries rather than operating in isolation.

Agentic Intelligence Across Finance and Controlling Functions

Finance processes within SAP are tightly governed. Yet they remain vulnerable to volume pressure, reconciliation delays, and data inconsistencies. Agentic AI in SAP introduces agents capable of interpreting transactional meaning instead of matching static fields.

For instance, agents that reconcile would review the intent of the posting as well as timing differences and relationships between companies to recommend changes rather than create exception lists. The transition from matching manually to validating decisions allows for faster closes and maintains accuracy.

Moreover, Agentic AI for SAP goes beyond finance by being used in controlling and forecasting. For example, agents that look at a Cost Center‚Äôs variance compared to plan provide warnings of potential future variances by correlating delayed purchasing, bottlenecking within operation, and price variability. Instead of standalone variance reports, the Finance team provides a context-specific recommendation with the ability to trace back to source information and assumptions.

Finally, Agentic AI for SAP provides a new definition of compliance monitoring; whereas previously, compliance would check after the posting, agents will check prior to posting, validating whether the transactions align with company policy as well as prior risk history. Predictive controls reduce the need for downstream corrections and/or auditing findings.

Typical finance use cases include:

  • Autonomous account reconciliation proposals
  • Predictive compliance validation
  • Contextual variance interpretation

SAP AI teams emphasize explainability in these scenarios. Each agent‚Äôs decision includes rationale, data references, and confidence levels. This maintains trust in regulated environments.

Supply Chain and Operations Under Agentic Control

All supply chains produce large amounts of 'signals', the variation in forecasts, supplier delays, and constraints on logistics result in a chain reaction. These types of 'volatility' are not well-suited to static planning models. An agentic AI is now available as part of SAP. It will allow automated agents to evaluate or negotiate the trade-offs between plans and adjust accordingly.

In demand planning, the AI agent will evaluate forecasts based on both recent and historical consumption and market signals. Instead of sending static alerts, AI agents in the SAP demand planning module will update the planning parameters. This allows for fewer manual overrides that affect the accuracy of the plan.

Operationally, agents monitor execution milestones. When deviations occur, they evaluate options across procurement, production, and distribution. Actions may include expediting materials, reallocating stock, or revising commitments. These decisions consider cost, service impact, and contractual obligations simultaneously.

Additionally, AI for SAP supports cross-functional coordination. Agents share context across modules rather than operating in isolation. This helps reduce fragmented responses and improves execution coherence.

Organizational Readiness and Governance Models

The implementation of agentic AI encompasses an organization‚Äôs readiness to use the agentic tool successfully. An organization‚Äôs level of readiness is determined by the organization‚Äôs ability to ensure data integrity, clarity of its business processes, and the level of governance that has been established.

First, data quality must support reasoning. Agents depend on consistent master data and reliable event streams. Skewed data leads to skewed decisions. Enterprises investing in agentic AI services often begin with semantic data alignment and process instrumentation.

Second, with evolving governance models, organizations set limits and thresholds that allow action authorization without the need for direct action approval for every action. AI agents within those limits and thresholds operate autonomously, with escalation of the process when risk increases or when agents are doubtful in their decision-making. This helps reduce the "approval fatigue" associated with governance models but still allows for oversight.

Security models are evolving as well, whereby agents receive scoped authority and scoped access controls, not only to see the data a user sees but also to take the action the user can take. The decisions that AI agents make in SAP are recorded alongside the decisions made by the human agents, creating one single audit trail for both human and AI agents.

Core governance principles include:

  • Explicit decision boundaries
  • Continuous monitoring of agent behavior
  • Transparent reasoning documentation

SAP AI Teams play a critical role here. They bridge business intent and technical design, ensuring agents act responsibly and predictably.

Final Thought

Agentic AI in SAP signals a structural shift in enterprise execution. SAP systems move beyond recording outcomes toward autonomous action. AI agents in SAP reason across modules, adjust to change, and act within defined constraints. Moreover, AI for SAP reshapes organizational roles and allows SAP teams to operate as agents of change rather than manual intervention.

To develop these agents, SAP teams will need to implement strict guidelines and oversight within their designs. Once agentic systems have been properly developed, they will provide a dependable means of digital operations for organizations to pursue. As more organizations adopt agentic AI into their SAP teams, the companies that invested time and effort into developing mature SAP AI teams and Agentic AI will be the companies establishing the standard for how intelligent enterprise execution will take place in the future.
